condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By the end of 2021 key communication outlets (media, mass organisations, youth media) have increased capacity to advocate for child rights.

description.narrative: UNICEF Laos, in collaboration with the LNR and MICT, has expanded youth engagement both online and offline, strengthened Lao journalists' capacity to report on issues affecting children's lives and raised awareness among children and youth about child rights, while promoting their participation in society as active citizens and offering them platforms to better report on child rights. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2019

title.narrative: Number of RCCE messages produced and disseminated with UNICEF support, adapted for target groups, in the reporting year [COVID]

Number of adolescent girls and boys who participate in or lead civic engagement (including online) in UNICEF-supported programmes for COVID-19 preparedness, response and building back better (more resilient, peaceful, greener and sustainable) in the reporting year [COVID] ii) Adolescent boys (10-19)
Number of youth who have been trained on child rights issues and express their views on issues affecting their lives
Number of articles/stories with UNICEF mentions in top-tier media outlets
Number of people reached on UNICEF/Youth Media social media channels
Communication platforms or networks supported by UNICEF meet quality standards for children and adolescent engagement and participation across development priorities
